title: 2025 Emmy Predictions: Who Will Win at the Primetime Emmy Awards?
description: With the Primetime Emmy Awards coming sooner than we all think, follow along for the latest predictions from IndieWire on how shows like "Hacks," "Adolescence," and "Severance" will fare.
author: Marcus Jones
excerpt: IndieWire shares its 2025 Emmy predictions for every major category, with insight on how favorite shows will fare at the 77th Primetime Emmy Awards.
text: Editor’s note: As Emmys season rolls along, IndieWire will update this page with in-depth Emmy predictions from Awards Editor Marcus Jones. A link to each category will lead to lists of the ever-changing contenders, plus reporting on what shows are playing well with voters, TV Academy rules changes, interviews with potential nominees, and more. The State of the Race As the TV season winds down, it’s time to begin the conversation around which shows will win at the 2025 Emmys. (It is!) The Television Academy will be looking to honor programs that aired between June 1, 2025 and May 31, 2025, a period of time still reeling from the widespread contraction of work in the industry, as well as the wildfires that devastated Los Angeles in January. However, unlike last year, which was jam-packed with two Emmys ceremonies, but was short on returning shows, the Outstanding Drama Series race alone has Emmy winners like “Severance,” “The White Lotus,” “The Last of Us,” “Squid Game,” and “The Handmaid’s Tale” all back in contention for more awards, as well as new hits like “The Pitt” on HBO Max, and “Paradise” on Hulu. Popular on IndieWire Similarly, “Hacks,” “The Bear,” “Abbott Elementary,” “Only Murders in the Building,” and the final season of “What We Do in the Shadows” are all back in the Outstanding Comedy Series race, which has gotten more and more competitive by the year. Netflix alone has produced enough new comedy series this season to fill the category, and “The Studio” on Apple TV+ introduced an instant classic awards scene that will probably end up with at least one Emmy winner thanking Sal Saperstein this year. Looking back at the winter awards season, not many new shows managed to break through, besides limited series “The Penguin” on HBO and “Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story” on Netflix. But as we saw with “Baby Reindeer” last year, there has still been room for more shows, from “Adolescence” to “Dying for Sex,” that were able to surprise and delight us in time for the first round of Emmys voting wraps on Monday, June 23, and nominations are announced on Tuesday, July 15.For more insight on the shows and stars we expect to be contenders this Emmys season, see the individual prediction pages listed below. IndieWire’s Emmy predictions will be refreshed throughout the race, so bookmark this page for the most accurate power rankings out there, and make sure to follow IndieWire on X, Facebook, and Instagram for all the latest Emmys news. Drama Series Outstanding Drama SeriesOutstanding Lead Actor in a Drama SeriesOutstanding Lead Actress in a Drama SeriesOutstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama SeriesOutstanding Supporting Actress in a Drama Series Comedy Series Outstanding Comedy SeriesOutstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy SeriesOutstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy SeriesOutstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy SeriesOutstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series Limited Series and TV Movie Outstanding Limited or Anthology SeriesOutstanding TV MovieOutstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series or a MovieOutstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series or a MovieOutstanding Supporting Actor in a Limited Series or a MovieOutstanding Supporting Actress in a Limited Series or a Movie Additional Predictions Outstanding Animated ProgramOutstanding Talk SeriesOutstanding Scripted Variety SeriesOutstanding Documentary or Nonfiction SeriesOutstanding Documentary or Nonfiction Special The nomination round of voting took place from June 12 to 23, with the official Emmy nominations being announced on Tuesday, July 15. Final voting will commence on August 18 and will close on the night of August 27. Finally, the 77th annual Primetime Emmy Awards are set to take place on Sunday, September 14, live on CBS at 8:00 p.m. ET/ 5:00 p.m. PT. Make sure to bookmark this landing page to stay in the loop on the latest news on the 2025 Primetime Emmy Awards race, and who we expect will be collecting trophies come September.
html:
Editor’s note: As Emmys season rolls along, IndieWire will update this page with in-depth Emmy predictions from Awards Editor Marcus Jones. A link to each category will lead to lists of the ever-changing contenders, plus reporting on what shows are playing well with voters, TV Academy rules changes, interviews with potential nominees, and more.

The State of the Race

As the TV season winds down, it’s time to begin the conversation around which shows will win at the 2025 Emmys. (It is!)

The Television Academy will be looking to honor programs that aired between June 1, 2025 and May 31, 2025, a period of time still reeling from the widespread contraction of work in the industry, as well as the wildfires that devastated Los Angeles in January.

However, unlike last year, which was jam-packed with two Emmys ceremonies, but was short on returning shows, the Outstanding Drama Series race alone has Emmy winners like “Severance,” “The White Lotus,” “The Last of Us,” “Squid Game,” and “The Handmaid’s Tale” all back in contention for more awards, as well as new hits like “The Pitt” on HBO Max, and “Paradise” on Hulu.

Popular on IndieWire

Similarly, “Hacks,” “The Bear,” “Abbott Elementary,” “Only Murders in the Building,” and the final season of “What We Do in the Shadows” are all back in the Outstanding Comedy Series race, which has gotten more and more competitive by the year. Netflix alone has produced enough new comedy series this season to fill the category, and “The Studio” on Apple TV+ introduced an instant classic awards scene that will probably end up with at least one Emmy winner thanking Sal Saperstein this year.

Looking back at the winter awards season, not many new shows managed to break through, besides limited series “The Penguin” on HBO and “Monsters: The Lyle and Erik Menendez Story” on Netflix. But as we saw with “Baby Reindeer” last year, there has still been room for more shows, from “Adolescence” to “Dying for Sex,” that were able to surprise and delight us in time for the first round of Emmys voting wraps on Monday, June 23, and nominations are announced on Tuesday, July 15.

For more insight on the shows and stars we expect to be contenders this Emmys season, see the individual prediction pages listed below. IndieWire’s Emmy predictions will be refreshed throughout the race, so bookmark this page for the most accurate power rankings out there, and make sure to follow IndieWire on X, Facebook, and Instagram for all the latest Emmys news.

Drama Series

Comedy Series

Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series or a Movie

Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Limited Series or a Movie

Additional Predictions

Outstanding Animated Program
Outstanding Talk Series
Outstanding Scripted Variety Series
Outstanding Documentary or Nonfiction Series
Outstanding Documentary or Nonfiction Special

The nomination round of voting took place from June 12 to 23, with the official Emmy nominations being announced on Tuesday, July 15. Final voting will commence on August 18 and will close on the night of August 27. Finally, the 77th annual Primetime Emmy Awards are set to take place on Sunday, September 14, live on CBS at 8:00 p.m. ET/ 5:00 p.m. PT.

Make sure to bookmark this landing page to stay in the loop on the latest news on the 2025 Primetime Emmy Awards race, and who we expect will be collecting trophies come September.
